clips.transcript_text: Can anybody [laughs] tell me what should I study in the university just to be a part of this magic?' And then, [laughs], a stranger of, uh, a stranger in the internet, whoever sees this comment, um, that person replied that says, 'You should just go for computer science.'
clips.notes: This is an amazing origin story, a 'butterfly effect' moment. It makes the listener wonder if she actually followed the advice and if that single comment truly shaped her career. clips.transcript_text: But then, uh, the, the school admission says, 'Hey, you are the only one who registered for computer science. Do you mind, like, changing a course?' [laughs]

clips.transcript_text: something that I told, told a lot of our members, our community members, is when you look back at the things that you do, even as a freelancer, content creator or whatnot, um, it's okay to feel cringe, but you don't really want to feel shame.

clips.transcript_text: Yes. I told Dave, uh, in a later interview, I said, 'Uh, Dave, I didn't have confidence. I outsourced my confidence to you, and thanks to you, I'm here.' [laughs] 'I'm in the game.' [laughs]

clips.transcript_text: So, like, don't hug the log when you have to climb the mountain. Yes, the log has saved you. It has served you in the past, but time to move on.

clips.transcript_text: Three times. Yeah? Okay. Three times that I have to be almost bedridden. [laughs] I'm in a lot of pain, uh, to realize, uh, I'm not supposed to do certain things. clips.transcript_text: I used to think that my existence is to be of use by others, is to lose my shapes and forms and then putting myself down to the dust, and to just serve others, and that is love. Mm-hmm. And that is contribution. That was my thinking- Mm-hmm ... back then.
